subject: Re: [junit] Testing persistence systems
msgSnippet: ... [...] ... An approach to unit testing that I take is to not test things that you re not responsible for.  I try very hard to not actually write to the
messageBody:
> Anyways, a testing issue that has been bothering me for a while is
> the issue of testing persistent storage.

[...]

> The point is, for a system like prevayler, in order to really confirm
> whether something has been persisted or not, you need to shut down
> the JVM, and then re-start and then check whether the object you
> persisted still exists.

An approach to unit testing that I take is to not test things that
you're not responsible for. I try very hard to not actually write to
the database, and leave that for automated integration tests*. My unit
tests use some kind of mock framework to simply verify that the code
that *I* wrote made the calls to the framework that I expected it to
make. Then I depend on the framework to do the right thing in the
'real' case.

You'll get problems if you misunderstand how to use the framework, but
that's something best caught in integration tests, especially when
you're talking about having to restart JVMs.

Kevin

*Currently our 'integration tests' are achieved through monkey-based
automation. That is, our smart QA people must behave like trained
monkeys and execute scripts for our applications "automatically" when
we have a new build. I recommend avoiding this route in favor of
automation tools or real monkeys. We're evaluating the former
currently, although I'm advocating the latter. If you can't have fun
at work, why work? Philistines.
